Comment: The Nimzo-Larsen Attack.

The strongest and most direct test of the Nimzo-Larsen is 1. ... e5; however, d5 is not a bad move. In fact, had the opponent played e5, I would most likely have the advantage in theoretical knowledge.

The fact that Black has not played e5 allows White to develop more aggressively with more control over the center. If e5 had been played, White could still play Nf3, but with ... e4, Black could gain more space and force the Knight to find a new home. If then Nd4, White's development becomes more cramped.

Black should have played 22. ... Rxe5. Then in order to retain any kind of advantage, White would play 23. fxg4, but White would have many weak, isolated pawns for Black to attack. Now, I maintain a much better position.

Black apparently doesn't want to give up his pressure on a5, but now, I get a free pawn and more pressure on the Black Kingside. The move should have been Re7.

Here I decided to go ahead and exchange some material for a position with a passed pawn and potential for another. Without the support of the King, Black's Queenside has no hope, but when the King supports the Queenside, White can force another passed pawn on the Kingside.
